title: Man pleads guilty to stealing Cle Elum fish hatchery equipment
title_page: Man pleads guilty to stealing Cle Elum fish hatchery equipment
maintext:
A Toppenish man pleaded guilty to theft and burglary of equipment from the Cle Elum fish hatchery on Monday.
Robert Bogar, 25, of Toppenish pleaded guilty to first-degree theft, second-degree burglary and first-degree trafficking in stolen items Monday in Kittitas County Superior Court. Deputy Prosecutor Candace Hooper dropped a second count of second-degree burglary. Superior Court Judge Scott Sparks sentenced Bogar to 15 months in prison.
Robert Bogar was living with his brother, Vernon, inside the Cle Elum fish hatchery at the time of the burglary. Vernon is accused of providing the keys to the hatchery to his brother. Robert was accused of taking about $8,000 in equipment out of the hatchery and selling it at a pawn store in Yakima, according to the probable cause statement.
Vernon Bogar is facing charges for first-degree theft and second-degree burglary. He pleaded not guilty to all charges in Superior Court on Nov. 7. He will have a status hearing before Sparks on Dec. 19.
